CDAs that did not include ICD-9 diagnostic codes were not among the most successful (data not shown) prescriptions for medications aimed at ARI symptoms and various groupings of antibiotics that could be used to treat bacterial pneumonias did not add value. the PPV of otherwise identical CDAs decreased 5.3–18% absolute percentages points compared to values obtained in the development phase of the study. the added imprecision occurred mostly in the outpatient arena (CDAs 5, 7, 12, 14, 19, 21, 26, 28, 33, 35, Tables 3–5) the ARI CDA was developed and validated against a population-based sample of over 15,000 EMR records. it recognized 99% of cases that satisfied a broad definition of ARI [10]. despite these differences, more than 95% of patients with Pneumonia-in-Plan satisfied the more permissive Possible Pneumonia definition in both our development and validation reference populations. prior attempts to automatically identify pneumonia patients have concentrated on diagnostic codes assigned after hospital discharge. discharge codes, however, are of limited value in epidemic surveillance because they are untimely and do not distinguish between community- and hospital-acquired pneumonia. classifying 26,581 imaging reports did more to improve detection performance than extracting ARI symptoms from almost 14 million clinical notes. however, our data support the notion that a generalized machine learning approach can perform well across information retrieval tasks [13], [14] our results represent a realistic environment in which to compare the relative performance of alternative detection approaches. an EMR-based approach that couples queries of structured data with text analysis of imaging reports can be used to assess disease severity in outpatients with ARI.
